nodes.bodyText: Done
isn't this "pattern" which I see repeated for processes and rules, a sympthom we don't have a clear API design at the Kogito platform level?

You are probably right: we generate classes using templates it is easy to remove an annotation and breaks without an integration tests that test it. I don't know if we can enforce this at API/design level to be honest 🤔
Any idea/suggestion?

No I don't think this is solvable within the scope of this PR.
I'm saying this sounded to me a symptom the design of the Kogito API has a problem.
I'm not sure I get this change, can you explain please?
thanks for the feedback; worthy of adding it as a // <code comment>?
Done 👍
since this change, and others below, shouldn't that reflect also on ALL the ...CompilationProvider classes??

nodes.bodyText:
@danielezonca
Maybe just a leftover, but I guess better to use directly "kieRuntimeFactoryFunction" instead of the getter method.
Beside that, as a side note, there is not null check/NPE protection.
Would it be possible to put the "kieRuntimeFactoryFunction" in the constructor ?
I see the setter is called in the template
public PredictionModels() { super(); setKieRuntimeFactoryFunction(sKieRuntimeFactoryFunction); } 
so - unless for other reasons - it would just be a matter of moving "sKieRuntimeFactoryFunction" inside the "super" invocation.
Done, I reviewed all the templates and now ~all the code is inside the abstract 👍

@danielezonca
If I'm not wrong, elsewhere in the code we have a strict naming convention.
As far as I see all this templates have the same schema: {context}{base model template} where "context" is "Cdi" or "Spring" and "base model template" is (for example) "PredictionModelsTemplate".
Would not be easier to just pass the latter (e.g. "PredictionModelsTemplate") to the "TemplatedGenerator", and have it infer the Cdi/Spring ones ? This would also enforce consistence between models, that is a good thing (IMHO).
Beside that, the only differences I see in the "models" templates, between different contexts, are the annotations on the class declaration (Cdi vs Spring ones). If/where this is true, I think it would be much better to remove all that useless duplications, have a "plain" template, and use JavaParser to dynamically add required annotation (Cdi/Spring) when needed.
All those templates are pretty cumbersome; whenever a modification is needed, it must be done twice; and, after all, they not really needed (again, IMVHO)
Done, I reviewed all the templates and now ~all the code is inside the abstract 👍

@danielezonca
Nice refactoring. Out of curiosity: is it needed for this method to be "static" ? I see it invoked inside a constructor
It is not invoked inside the constructor but with a static block (i.e. link)
Thx, misread 👍

@danielezonca
Fine if it works.
Anyway, all that still look as a painful workaround related to https://issues.redhat.com/browse/DROOLS-5724.
If I'm not wrong it all depends on the fact that DMN requires PMML for validation at building time (inside its Kogito-specific builder) even if NULL (as currently is), while model validation should be managed in previous step and should be model specific.

If I'm not wrong it all depends on the fact that DMN requires PMML for validation at building time

This assessment is incorrect.
This was already explained in the JIRA history (ref https://issues.redhat.com/browse/DROOLS-5724?focusedCommentId=15374787&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-15374787 ) and followed up with the Kogito leads responsible for the previous Vs current directives.
Yes DMN internals will be refactored as part of DROOLS-5724 anyway.
I added a comment to explain the reason of the AtomicReference. I tested it both jvm and native mode so we have the possibility to approach other refactoring incrementally without block this PR
DecisionModels should be injectable and same instance application.decisionModels() - probably same instance as application.decisionModels()?
Done
Same here.
Done
And here.
Done

I know that generated code probably shouldn't be readable that much, but wouldn't it be better to leave the imports here to make it cleaner? If the class is moved in future to a different package, we will have to change the templates anyway.

In general I prefer to be on the safe side with templates: when we add code to the template it could produce name clashing while with FQCN this should not happen. Btw no strong opinion, if you prefer I can revert
Makes sense, thanks!
So the static block is used because of the CDI as we have to have a no-arg constructor? (Otherwise we would use just parameters of the constructor...)

No here the problem is that both DMN and PMML has some static code to be executed to load files. This is a trick for native compilation (and avoid parsing at runtime). So instead of duplicate this static code in all the templates, I moved it to the abstract class and created this init static method that is invoked in a static block codegenerated with the arguments.
